clinical_study.brief_title: Thoracic Paravertebral Blockade in Video Assisted Thoracoscopic Surgery (VATS)
clinical_study.official_title: Effects of Thoracic Paravertebral Blockade on Acute and Chronic Pain After Video Assisted Thoracoscopic Surgery (VATS) - A Randomized, Clinical Trial

brief_summary.textblock: Video-assisted thoracoscopic surgeries (VATS) include severe postoperative acute pain which is also a predictor of chronic pain. In this study, the investigators aim to compare the postoperative effects of thoracic paravertebral block (TPVB) and intravenous patient controlled analgesia (PCA) on the prevention of chronic pain of patients undergoing VATS.

detailed_description.textblock:
Video-assisted thoracoscopic surgeries (VATS) include significant postoperative acute and chronic pain because of trocar site tissue damages, intercostal nerve injuries and related inflammatory responses. Poorly controlled pain in the early postoperative period usually causes chronic pain, and also affects patients' physiotherapy, mobilization and daily function.
Our hypothesis in this study is 'thoracic paravertebral block (TPVB) is associated with an improvement in control of acute and chronic pain after VATS compared to systemic analgesia.

primary_outcome.measure: Postoperative chronic pain scores (VAS) at rest and during mobilization

secondary_outcome.measure: Postoperative acute pain at rest and during coughing/mobilization
Postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV) and antiemetic requirements
secondary_outcome.description: Postoperative acute PONV and antiemetic use follow-up
Postoperative IV PCA morphine consumption for Group 1 and IV morphine consumption for Group 2 as rescue analgesic
Postoperative first analgesic IV PCA morphine demand time for Group 1 and first rescue analgesic IV morphine time for Group 2

secondary_outcome.measure: Postoperative first oral intake, flatulence, defecation, mobilization times
secondary_outcome.description: Postoperative first oral intake, flatulence, defecation, mobilization times

secondary_outcome.measure: Postoperative hospital discharge day and time
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Participants is being followed for the duration of hospital stay, an expected average of 1 week
secondary_outcome.description: Postoperative hospital discharge day and time

secondary_outcome.measure: Postoperative long term (1st, 3rd and 6th months) analgesic, sleep quality and comfort follow-up
secondary_outcome.description: Postoperative long term (1st, 3rd and 6th months) analgesic, sleep quality and comfort follow-up with phone call

arm_group.description: Postoperative intravenous (IV) morphine PCA is being used for acute pain control: Basal infusion: 0.3 mg/kg/h Bolus: 1 mg, Lock-out time: 20 min, 4-h limit: 10-12,5 mg
Preoperative thoracic paravertebral block (TPVB) at 4 levels from T4 to T8 is being performed and total of 20 mL Bupivacaine 0.5% is deposited (5 mL per level by using landmark technique)

intervention.description: Thoracic paravertebral block (TPVB) is being performed by injecting 5 mL of Bupivacaine 0.5% to 4 consecutive level of paravertebral spaces between T4 and T8 by using landmark technique
IV morphine patient controlled analgesia (PCA) is being used in the postoperative period for 48 hours. Basal infusion: 0.3 mg/kg/h, Bolus: 1 mg, Lock-out time: 20 min, 4-h limit: 10-12,5 mg

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
ASA I-III Patients who undergo Video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery (VATS) under GA
Exclusion Criteria:
Patients with difficult understanding the instructions for using PCA and/or pain scales Patients with contraindication to regional anesthesia Patients with significant neurologic, psychiatric or cognitive disorders History of substance abuse or chronic opioid use
